title: toggling editor.minimap.renderCharacters changes minimap display size significantly
body: Issue Type: Bug Setting editor.minimap.renderCharacters to false increases the height of the minimap by 150% vs setting it to true, which means that fewer minimap lines fit on the screen. I would expect rendering text vs rendering blocks to occupy the same amount of vertical space since they occupy the same amount of horizontal space. VS Code version: Code 1.24.1 (24f62626b222e9a8313213fb64b10d741a326288, 2018-06-13T17:41:50.128Z) OS version: Darwin x64 17.4.0

title: Add DecorationRangeBehavior.Word

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
From #50779

**Problem**
Using decorators, a common pattern is that you want an decoration that applies to a given whole word. None of the current `DecorationRangeBehavior` values handle this well. `Open` will always expand the decorator even if you type non-word characters, while `Close` never expands the decorator

**Proposal**
Add a `DecorationRangeBehavior.Word` setting or similar that would expand the decoration if the edit extends the word at the edges of the decoration. Typing a word character would expand the decorator while typing space would not

title: Instructor Mode
body:
As per the conversation with @auchenberg and @chrisdias, it's been requested by a number of instructors to take zen mode one step further. The expected behavior would:

- Have no LOC numbers visible
- Go full screen
- Remove the icons from the top right
- Have no tabs
- Be available and removed on a toggle

cc @johnpapa @kentcdodds @eggheadio @elijahmanor

Please feel free to add to this thread if I've misrepresented anything. Thank you for your time and effort in this!

title: Prevent accidentally staging or unstaging files when commit is in progress

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.24.0
- OS Version: macOS High Sierra 10.13.5
- Source Control: Git

### Description:

Files are able to be staged/unstaged even if a commit is currently in progress. This can lead to accidental file commits or the opposite (accidentally removing a file from a commit). 

I did not expect to be able to change the set of the files once a commit has been initiated and assumed any subsequent stages would be queued for a future commit or perhaps it would be possible to disable the stage/unstage buttons when a commit is running?

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have multiple files changes in your repo
2. Stage one of these files
3. Enter a message and and press Cmd+Enter to commit
4. Stage another file whilst step (3) is still running 

### Result
The file staged in step 4 is now included as part of the commit initiated in step 3. **Step 3 may take a while, for example if automatic code formatting or unit tests are run as a pre-commit hook.**

title: Feature: Use package.json to save state of extensions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
One of extensions have regression so downgrading it and  freezing extension to **specific** version is not possible. I have to freeze all automatic updates and manually find vsix for old version and install it.

**This is hot shit**

My idea is that there is package.json file in global settings of vscode and we use npm dependancies(vscode extension projects) to list the extensions.

- This will reduce developer learning curve for creating extensions.
- One can freeze particular extension version, or auto update minor versions, or major
e.g 
```
{
  "dependencies": {
    "@marketplace/piotrpalarz.vscode-gitignore-generator": "^1.2.2",
    "extension" : "git://github.com/user/extension.git#commit-ish",
    "@marketplace/ms-vscode.cpptools": "2.3.2",
    "jas99/myextension": "~1.1.0", // by default use github
    "@gitlab.com/jas99/myextension": "1.0"
  }
}

```

In addition to that one can also load dependencies/extensions with local package.json file in workspace settings.

Thx

title: Default extensions scope

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Hi,
Curently when you install extension it will be installed in global scope (used for all projects), I think it can be useful to have settings to set default installation scope, such as `current workspace`, `global scope`, maybe even `current session`. Because:

1. If you use VS Code for many different projects (different languages/frameworks) you will load unneeded extensions every time that will slow down start up 
2. Some extensions can have conflicts between each other
3. Some extensions is badly written and can throw error messages if they can't find required files in current workspace
4. Maybe you need to use this extension rarely or only once.

It should be allowed to change this setting from user settings. Possible values:

1. Current workspace 
2. Global workspace (installation default)
3. ??? Current session (not sure if this needed, but some extensions used quite rare, for example screen sharing or something similar)

Also it should be possible to select one of this options from combobox in extension store.

If this will be approved I want to handle pull request for this issue.

Maybe related to:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/49826
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/47053

title: Place scrollbarSlider.background below syntax blocks/characters in minimap

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: Hi. Thanks for the latest release! Loving the latest features. I'm a themer and I've noticed that to make the minimap background look good, I need to use a transparent colour for `scrollbarSlider.background`; otherwise the built-in amount of transparency used is still quite dark: I was wondering if it'd be a good idea if the syntax characters/blocks could be _on top of_ the highlight, meaning I can work easier with solid colours and not need think about how much transparency Code is going to add for me (because it wouldn't be needed any more).

title: Commands executed from command palette are not logged
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.24.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Step to reproduce:
1. Set log level to trace.
2. Execute command using keyboard shortcut
3. Check command log in output panel - command logged.
4. Execute same command using command palette.
5. Check command log in output panel - command is not logged. 
![code_log_commands](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14140583/41194561-57019a62-6c1d-11e8-9a68-dcaa3857ec92.gif)  

Expected behavior:
Commands executed from command palette are logged to output panel.

title: Text expansion utilities dont work correctly
body:
When using a text expansion utility (aText on macOS, Breevy on Windows 10), the text used to trigger the expansion is not replaced correctly in VS Code.

In this example, we use the trigger `\lipsumm` to expand some placeholder text. On VS Code, the first six characters, `\lipsu`, remain after the placeholder text is inserted.

![vs-code-text-expansion](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1298049/41187316-d776bcce-6bd0-11e8-96eb-a2efc9c859d8.jpg)

In all other tested applications (eg, Atom, Emacs, Vim, Firefox, Word), the entire trigger is correctly replaced.

body: Looks like cmd+u is available to undo your cursor positioning, but there is no cursorRedo function. cmd+shift+u brings up the output pane. In sublime text, cmd+shift+u is a cursor redo shortcut. I'd like to be able to redo cursor positioning.

title: Promise with no error log error.stack
body:
Some non handled promises are not logged at all (so was impossible to know where the error happened). One example is calling`TreeView.reveal()` with `TreeDataProvider` that doesn't implement `getParent()` : In that case I expect to see at least the following message (and a stack if possible):

`Required registered `TreeDataProvider` to implement 'getParent' method to access 'reveal' method`

Actual behavior: nothing is shown, just the message "WARNING: Promise with no error callback" 

 I was able to reproduce this in vscode master  creating a very simple extension that just did that. Don't know / don't have the time to investigate if the real issue is when the promise is created instead of in this part of the code. Notice I don't want only to print just the stack but also the message, logging error.error did the trick

Thanks

title: Default action for `ctrl + a` should be `cursorEnd`, not `cursorLineStart`
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.24.0
- OS Version: macOS High Sierra, 10.13.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type ctrl+a
2. Expected: cursor moves to leftmost non-whitespace character
3. Actual: cursor moves to column 0

This is a reopening of #47319, which was previously closed with the note that keybindings are customizable. My suggestion is that the default keybinding be changed to match macOS user expectations.

The current default is:
```
{ "key": "ctrl+e",                "command": "cursorLineEnd",
                                     "when": "textInputFocus" },
{ "key": "ctrl+a",                "command": "cursorLineStart",
                                     "when": "textInputFocus" },
```

The more idiomatic default would be:
```
{ "key": "ctrl+e",                "command": "cursorEnd",
                                     "when": "textInputFocus" },
{ "key": "ctrl+a",                "command": "cursorHome",
                                     "when": "textInputFocus" },
```

title: Update paths not triggered on rename if you have never opened a js/ts file
body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an empty workspace with two ts files in it:

`a.ts`:
```ts
export const a = 1;
```

`b.ts`:
```ts
import { a } from './a';
console.log(a);
```

2. Close all files and restart vscode.
3. Without opening any ts file, use the explorer to rename `a.ts` to `x.ts`

**Bug**
No update paths prompt shown

title: cursorWordStartLeft etc. do not manage undo history properly
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.23.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make a new document
2. enter this: `foo bar baz`
3. ctrl+left twice; the cursor should be before bar.... that is: `foo |bar baz`
4. type `q` so we have `foo q|bar baz`
5. hit ctrl+z
6a. result: `foo bar|`
6b. expected result: `foo |bar baz`

Compare to visual studio, firefox.

You will also notice a discrepancy between how those others do things, and how you're likely to end up doing it. I do not object to this discrepancy.

Subsequent undo steps in FF, VS: `foo |bar baz`, `<empty string>`
Subsequent undo steps in chrome: buggy and apparently nondeterministic
Likely to be subsequent steps in VSCode, ideally, after bug is fixed: `foo |bar baz`, `foo bar|`, `foo|`, `<empty string>`

Additional steps, as justification--you can see why the behaviour is expected by considering ctrl+left to be a shortcut for hitting left several times:

7. After typing `foo bar baz` press left until you get to `foo |bar baz`
8. type `q` so we have `foo q|bar baz`
9. repeat undoing and watch it work as "likely to be subsequent steps in VSCode, ideally, after bug is fixed"

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: addSelectionToNextFindMatch  & doubleclick sense of selection is inconsistent wrt themselves & other commands
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.23.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

In a nutshell: 
1. addSelectionToNextFindMatch selection does not match doubleclick.
2. doubleclick selection is not always logical

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make a new untitled document
2. Enter `alpha == beta  gamma`. Please note there are two spaces between beta and gamma despite my markdown indicating that it's preformatted.
3. Issue addSelectionToNextFindMatch via keybinding on alpha: note that it works
4. Issue addSelectionToNextFindMatch via keybinding on ==: note, that it does nothing. Repeat that test from any cursor position before, inside, or after ==. It never works.
5. Double-click the `=` to the right: the word gets selected. This is as expected.
6. Double-click the `=` to the left: the space before the == gets selected. This is wrong.

Maybe relatedly but not as big a deal:
7. Double-click the space after alpha. The word itself selects, rather than the space. This is wrong, or at least illogical. However, since VS does it wrongly this way too, I'm not going to complain.
8. Double-click the space after the ==. The space selects, as expected
9. Double-click the space after beta. Beta selects. Same as in item 7; it's weird
10. Double-click the NEXT space after beta. The spaces select, as expected.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: option to display parameter info tooltip in a separate pannel

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Instead of displaying the parameter info tooltip next to cursor, I would like to have an option to display it in a separate panel, maybe a "documentation" panel next to Problems / Output / Debug Console / Terminal.

Some of us disable these tooltips because we find them annoying. However, we find them useful and it would be a good compromise to have them available somewhere.

This idea is from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/33752#issuecomment-340151000
